metadata.title: Why Should Data Scientists use Functions? | by Renan Lolico | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: Why Should Data Scientists use Functions?
metadata.description: Start to reuse code to gain hours of improvement on big projects!

all_paragraphs: I've been working as a Software Engineer even before starting to learn about Data Science in the past years, it gives me a comprehension of an issue that, commonly, starters don't catch: breaking the code into blocks with functions.

The last years bring a hype on the Data Science field, allowing it to grow at an exponential speed; With the advent of the internet, now learners can simply go to YouTube or Medium and start to understand and apply everything.
Now, let's check the main difference between these standard approaches together.

I don't know your learning process, but during my Data Science lessons, I've faced a problem: In order to deliver the content in an easier way, our teachers commonly prefer to avoid complexity things; Why should they wrap the code inside a function if it'll make the explanation really difficult later on?
I remember that, in one of my lessons, my instructor said the following:
“Remember the function we had to write in the last class? It won’t work, actually, it was my mistake; but we won’t waste time on that, just write the following code…”

That was the real mistake! Instead of rewriting the function, fixing the issues, allowing us to know how it works and how beneficial the functions can be, we've been taught to avoid it, just because one single line of code can break the entire project. He ignored the entire capacity of the function system just because of a single issue.
Today, we’ll dive into the importance of the functions; To make it easy, let’s use a simple example: discover the BMI of a person. We’ll be using the metric version, so the formula is the following:

Well, here we’ve used a method that uses two "brute" numbers; It was really easy to do, right? You just give access to both numbers and, from that, insert the result on the new variable, really impressive.
You can add some level of abstraction by changing the fixed number into a variable, this way we can easily change the numbers to sum by simply modifying this variable, let's check:

This works in an impressive way for starters, but let’s check the main issue: modifications. Now we have a list of weights and heights to measure the BMI, we need to wrap the code inside a loop… and some problems start to appear.
There are some issues here, let's enumerate then:
I think that now you started to understand how important functions are for everyone, but for us, Data Scientists, it becomes a trivial part of working with data;

Let's modify the context now: Let's say that we've been collecting the BMI results from a random person for five months and need to give different advice for that. First, let's take a look at the dataset.

As you can check above there is nothing special there, right? Just data on a DataFrame, really simple; But how about Feature Engineering? How could you get important insights from data? Advice: without functions, it's really hard; As I said before, functions is a trivial part of the Data Scientist routine, you need to use it. Let's verify a single function that matches really well with our context:

Woah! What is that? Calm down, take an accurate look on the function first, it’s nothing hard to understand, it’s just the difference between the actual weight and the past month one; Now, our DataFrame looks like that:

Remember the code that we've added inside a loop at the beginning of this article? The one that isn't really abstract when working with real Data Science projects? Let's take a look on its function version:
As you can see, now we're able to work with Feature Engineering in an easy way, writing reusable code; At the end of the day, our DataFrame looks like that:

With this function, now we're able to work with future data without any issues; You can call it whenever you want to predict the BMI of any person, in other words, now you can work without worrying about the so-called boilerplate. Take a look at the gif below:

The more time you waste rewriting code, the less you will be applying your energy on things that really matter; Reuse code! The Data Science fieldwork with big data, which means that every single second count on the performance.
I hope you enjoyed this content and can apply your new knowledge with mastery! If you want to keep learning something interesting every day, I’ll be happy to share great content with you!
In addition, you can check my profile on Github. All the key concepts are there to learn and reuse!
Your home for data science. A Medium publication sharing concepts, ideas and codes.
I share concepts that are worthwhile.
